title: Mont Blanc // My 3rd Attempt to Climb Western Europes Highest Peak
description: I've travelled to Chamonix twice before with the intention of climbing the surprisingly deadly Mont Blanc. On both previous attempts we got rained out and spent our time under a gloomy sky. This time however, the sun shone brightly on Chamonix and the surrounding Mont Blanc Massif. After failing to accurately research our trip we found ourselves driving a poorly equipped 2 wheel drive rental up to Col De Voza. From there we took the normal route or the Goûter Route up to Tête Rousse. Our original plan was to stay at a different refuge but nothing we kinda planned really worked out. So we improvised all the way to the summit which according to recent news has shrunk by 3 feet. Thank goodness, I'm not sure Christof could have handled another 3 feet.

title: Lake Louise // Niblock and Whyte A Top Ten Scramble in Banff
description: I’ve seen a lot of pictures of Lake Louise and it’s red canoes. And in person it did not disappoint. Nestled in the heart of Banff National Park, Lake Louise offers loads of hikes with lots of dazzling views. For this visit I decided to do the Niblock to Whyte scramble with a descent down to the Plain of the Six Glaciers Teahouse. As a bonus summit I also climb up Devils Thumb with nick before ditching him for higher ground. I started at the Lake Louise Hotel and took the trail up to the Agnus Lake Teahouse. From there I climbed up to the Devils thumb then down the backside on a primitive trail.  After descending the Thumb I caught the faint trail to the saddle between Niblock and Whyte. I summited Nibloc first then did the loose scramble to Mount Whyte. After that I scrambled the ridge to the south then descending through thousands of feet of scree back to the Plain of the Six Glaciers trail.

title: Banff National Park // Mt Temple Scramble
description: I've been wanting to go to Banff National Park for years. I've wanted to climb Mt Temple because it's one of the first trails in Banff I ever heard of. It took a couple of years and a few false starts but eventually I made it to Canada's endless mountain splendor in Banff.  Unfortunately, I couldn't get anyone else to go. But at the 11th hour I threw out a hail mary to wildlife artist Nick Coleman. Not only did he agree to get tested for Covid and go, he even agreed to drive. This trail starts at Lake Moraine and goes straight up 5,000ft in 5 miles. The Mt Temple trail slowly reveals a glacier spotted landscape with blue alpine lakes and rugged mountains in every direction. It's awesome.

title: The Cosmique Arete // 3 Feet of Fresh Snow in July
description: On the Aiguille du Midi there's a route, supposedly a Chamonix classic, called the Cosmique Arete. It's a great route, with amazing rock, rappels and views and I didn't know it existed until we were half way through it. Sometimes you follow the crowd and end up with bedazzled, flared jeans and a frohawk. Other times you wind up doing something you'll want to tell your kids about, like climbing the Cosmique Arete under the pressing stare of a snow covered Blanc Massif. Fresh snow was definitely present during our time above Chamonix. It seemed as if 3 feet of thick, dense snow had fallen just prior to our arrival. It made things feel majestic but also unusually dangerous for a July assault on Blanc.

title: Breithorn // The Matterhorn's Neighbor
description: When there's rain and snow in the middle of July you've got to keep you mountain plans flexible. This episode begins on a rain and thunder morning in Wengen, Switzerland. With little hope of a clearing we casually work our way to Zermatt, Switzerland. Where the weather is still nothing but hard rain and thunder. As the day ends, there's little hope of a Matterhorn summit. So we console ourselves the next day with a small peak called Breithorn during a short break between storms.

title: Jungfrau // Chasing the Weather in the Bernese Alps
description: The Jungfrau is one of the commanding summits in the Bernese Alps and towers over the Lauterbrunnen Valley at 13,642 feet. It sits close to the Eiger and access to it's imposing glacier can be had by taking a train that tunnels through the belly of the Eiger to the Jungfraujoch. The whole experience, from the train ride to the summit climb is mind blowing.

title: Guggihütte // In the Shadow of the Eiger
description: After two years of talking about it we finally get back to Europe on what turned out to be one of the wettest summers on record. This means making the most of our time in the sun. So just hours after touching down, and 24 sleepless hours since leaving home, we suit up for a run to the Guggi Hut on the flank of the fabled Eiger mountain in Switzerland. I can’t think of a better way to start our Europe adventure than in the shadow of the Eiger and Jungfrau. We’ve got big plans for our time in Switzerland and France but the weather might require some adjusting. Luckily there are unlimited mountain opportunities in the Alps. Our trip starts here in Wengen which is in the Lauterbrunnen valley two hours from Zurich and just south of Interlaken.

title: Teewinot Mountain // The Best View in the Tetons
description: Went into this hike not knowing what to expect. Wasn’t even planning on turning the climbing of Teewinot into an episode. But the mountain and trail just became more spectacular as we ascended. By the summit I was glad I had hit record. Teewinot Mountain provides one of the best summit views in Grand Teton National Park. I’ve stared up at it’s summit from Lupine Meadows numerous times and I’m glad I finally got around to climbing it. It’s a quad buster for sure but the trail quickly becomes a challenging scramble that helps you forget the fire in your legs.

title: Three Sisters Wilderness // Skiing the North and Middle Sister
description: Thanks to all the people we met on the trail for stopping and saying hello. You help keep the stoke alive. In this episode we set out to summit the North Sister in the Three Sisters Wilderness. A day or two earlier a small storm with strong winds had plastered the rock faces on the west slope with thick rime ice.  As we rounded the corner onto the west face the mountain seemed to fall apart as chunks of ice constantly broke off and tumbled by. So the Amateurs regrouped and discussed their situation. Should we summit or should we go over and ski the very appealing Middle Sister? Also, didn't even notice matts joker sunscreen look until I got home and looked at the footage.

title: The White Rim Trail // 100 Miles of Canyonlands in a Day
description: The White Rim Trail is a 100 mile jeep road that cuts through some of the most scenic parts of Canyonlands National Park. We decided to do the loop counter clockwise and start at the entrance for the park. It was Christofs birthday wish to ride this loop otherwise I probably never would have done it. I'm glad I did. I'm even more glad I did it on a day when the temperatures were peaking at 80. These 100 miles expose the rider to a lot of desert views as the trail runs along the Green and Colorado river. Candle stick tower, Junction bluff, Washerwoman and Airport tower will forever be seared in my mind as we slowly road around these name worthy landmarks on the sand and sandstone trails that make up The White Rim.

title: Mount Sneffels // Skiing Snake Couloir on my New Favorite Colorado 14er
description: You can be drawn to a mountain for many reasons  such as height, location, or in the case of this mountain, a name. I’ve wanted to climb this peak ever since I saw the name on google maps. Having it also make the list of Colorados 14ers was just a nice bonus. In this episode we climb Mount Sneffels via the Snake Couloir starting at the Blue Lakes Trailhead. Also, a true friend tells you when you have something in your teeth. I guess none of my adventure buddies are true friends cause I've always got stuff in my teeth.

title: The La Sals // Skiing White Peaks Above Red Rocks
description: 20 miles east of Arches National Park, Canyonlands, and Moab there is a mountain range that has caught our attention since high school. While running or biking in Moab we'd gaze off into the distance at Mount Peale and Mount Tukuhnikivatz and think it would be awesome to ski those" than we'd instantly brush off the idea because it was spring time and we had already checked out of ski mode. The last two years we managed to keep the idea front and center and then in mid March we managed to pull it off with the help of a surprise late season snow dump. It was as spectacular as we had imagined when we first saw those salty peaks."

title: Muir Woods // Running in the Redwoods
description: The day after skiing in Crater Lake National Park we went for a 24 Mile run on some of the most beautiful trails in Northern California. From redwoods, to mountain top views, and scenic beach this run provides a kaleidoscope of ever changing scenery. The smell of the ocean and the abundance of oxygen must also have  had a calming effect on Matt and Christof. It took all the best impatient looks and gestures to get them out of the cafe and off the beach back into the mountains.

title: Crater Lake National Park // Skiing Short Shots for the View
description: With a persistent weak layer coating the mountains from Canada to California we scoured the land for the safest and most scenic ski tour. We eventually settled on crater lake national park. On of the best ski strolls I’ve ever taken. We even managed to ski a meager 500ft or so down the face of watchman peak. All in all a great day at one of the premier pre historic disaster areas in North America.

title: Mount Baker // Skiing the Coleman Deming Route in Winter
description: Mount Baker is an awesome mountain. The peak is that much more mind blowing when you can scale its heights on a sunny no wind day. You can see a lot of iconic landmarks from the summit of Baker. Glacier peak, Rainier, and Olympic National Park. If, and that’s a big if, you can catch it on a good day like we did. On this episode we climb and ski Mount Baker via the Coleman Deming route. Skiing from the summit to the car provides nearly 8,000 ft of descent. Snow conditions ranged from ice to 6 inches of light powder. Definitely a radical day with a little of everything.

title: Teton Crest Trail // Running One of The Classics
description: See it all on this classic, bucket list trail. On the TCT you get to enjoy Grand Teton National Park end to end in all its splendor. 38 miles and 9,000ft of trail running and power walking bliss from canyon to shelf to basin, pass and divide. Just remember to bring along a friend in worse shape than yourself. Then you can enjoy this iconic trail at a leisurely pace and really take it all in.

title: Mount Moran // CMC to the Summit
description: During a weekend in September we set out to summit Mount Moran via the CMC route. We decided to paddle board to the foot of the mountain, something I was less than comfortable with. My fear of water can not be overestimated. After surviving my encounter with the dark, cold water of Lake Leigh we set off on foot 6,000ft up the mountain to the sold rock face of the CMC route. It was there that we confronted the rope or no rope dilemma. Also, yes life vests would have been nice. You’d think an aquaphobic such as myself would have worn two or three at the same time. Unfortunately that large rock face loomed large in our minds and pretty much blocked out everything else.

title: Glacier National Park // The Floral Park Traverse
description: First let me explain the seemingly cold and callous reaction of my friends to my situation 3/4 of the way through this video. Everyone there has seen me spiral. They all know that there’s little they can do but make light of the situation and take some satisfaction in the fact that it’s not them feeling like they just got off the teacup ride at Disneyland. However, behind all the jokes made at my expense there’s a knowledge that they would do anything to make sure I don’t die out there. Also, I would definitely be making fun of them if the roles were reversed. When we set out on this adventure we didn’t know it had a name until a stranger on the trail educated us on it’s existence. Turns out we were attempting the Floral Park Traverse, a very aptly named 26 miles of floral splendor through Glacier National Park. This episode was filmed August 2. I’m not sure if that's peak flower time but it sure felt like it.

title: Pioneer Peak // The Real Summit
description: Some friends push you to spend money on  scenic flights while other friends might push you to go run until 11pm the day before a big day out. Either way you’ll be happy you listened to your friend. At least until your wife sees the bill or your knee needs surgery. On this episode we wrap up our Alaskan adventure with a 7500 ft climb to the summit of Pioneer Peak in the Chugach mountain range. The perfect ending for a hard charging trip to the last frontier. Seriously though, my wife must never find out how much I spent on that scenic flight.

title: Denali National Park // Riding the Park Road
description: After testing negative for Covid we take our test results and head to the last frontier, Alaska. Riding the Denali Park Road has been a dream of Matt’s since he drove it on a bus almost 1 year ago. He’s talked non stop about riding all 92 miles of its majestic gravel glory ever since that fateful bus ride. We watched the weather for months and after spotting a weather trend in the right direction took off for Denali only to arrive during a rain storm. Will the weather clear up and give us that rare glimpse of Denali or will my 3rd bike ride for the year end in rain soaked gear and an extreme saddle sore?
